questions.question: Which of the following best describes Tangier disease?
questions.explanation: due to mutations in the ABCA1 gene on chromosome 9q31 , which impairs cholesterol transport. Defects in ABCA1 are characterized by two clinical hallmarks; enlarged lipid-laden tonsils and low serum HDL. Also known as Familial alpha-lipoprotein deficiency/Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia. This mutation causes a decreased level of Apo A1,where HDL is not properly formed. Leads to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues such as the tonsils, liver, spleen, and corneas. Clinical features : Include enlarged orange-colored tonsils, peripheral neuropathy, hepatosplenomegaly and early-onset cardiovascular disease. Low VLDL levels (Option A) are not characteristic of Tangier disease. VLDL primarily carries triglycerides, and its levels are not significantly affected in Tangier disease. Low LDL levels (Option C) are not specifically affected in Tangier disease. LDL primarily carries cholesterol to tissues, and its levels can vary independently of HDL levels. Low LDL receptor activity (Option D): This describes familial hypercholesterolemia, not Tangier disease. Familial hypercholesterolemia is characterized by high LDL cholesterol levels due to defective LDL receptors on cell surfaces. Reference: Lippincott Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Page 678

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presents with developmental delays, visual impairment, and recurrent episodes of ataxia. Laboratory tests reveal low serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins. A blood smear shows the presence of acanthocytes. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?

options.A: Elevated levels of chylomicrons in the bloodstream.
options.D: High serum levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

questions.explanation: Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the inability to synthesize apolipoprotein B ( Apo B ), which is essential for the formation of certain lipoproteins. Pathophysiology : Caused by mutations in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene. Leads to impaired assembly and secretion of lipoproteins, particularly chylomicrons and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). (Option A and D ruled out) Results in low serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). Clinical Features : Fat malabsorption leads to steatorrhea (fatty stools). (Option C ruled out) Deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins can cause: Retinitis pigmentosa (leading to blindness). Neurological deficits (e.g., ataxia, developmental delays). Presence of acanthocytes (spiny red blood cells) on blood smear. Management : Dietary management to provide essential fatty acids and fat-soluble vitamins. Supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) may be beneficial. Reference: Vasudevan Biochemistry, 7th Edition Page 341, 342

questions.question: A researcher is studying the mechanisms of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in post-heparinized blood samples. They conduct a mixing study to differentiate between a deficiency of apolipoprotein C-II (Apo C-II) and LPL deficiency. Which of the following outcomes from the mixing study would most accurately indicate an Apo C-II deficiency?

options.A: The addition of pooled normal plasma results in no change in LPL activity.
options.B: LPL activity normalizes after mixing with normal plasma.
options.C: A significant increase in triglyceride levels is observed after mixing.
options.D: LPL activity decreases following the addition of normal plasma.

questions.explanation: are used because heparin in circulation competes with heparan sulfate on vessel walls, causing enzymes to detach from the vessel wall and attach to circulating heparin. If LPL activity is low in post-heparinized individuals, it is either an Apo C II defect or an LPL defect. Mixing study to differentiate Apo C defect from LPL defect: In the patients post heparinized plasma, add an equal amount of pooled normal plasma which acts as a source of apo C II. If LPL activity normalizes it is an apo C II defect and it will respond to FFP administration. If LPL activity does not normalize it is an LPL defect (Option A). An increase in triglyceride levels is not indicative of Apo C-II deficiency and does not relate directly to the expected outcomes of the mixing study. (Option C) Decrease in LPL activity after mixing would suggest an error in the experiment or another underlying issue, not an Apo C-II deficiency. (Option D) Reference: Vasudevan Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Page 176

Nutritional Deficiencies Deficiencies in essential fatty acids, vitamins ( linoleic acid, pyridoxine, pantothenic acid) , and protein contribute to fatty liver. questions.question: Which among the following is a true statement on electrophoretic mobility of lipoproteins seen during serum electrophoresis?

options.A: HDL shows the least mobility due to high lipid content.
options.B: Lipoproteins with higher protein content move slower towards the anode.
options.C: Lipoproteins with higher protein content migrate faster towards the anode
options.D: Lipoproteins identified by dye color after staining with lipid dyes, not electrophoretic mobility.

questions.explanation: stained with lipid dyes, such as Oil Red O. Higher protein content will move faster towards the anode and those with less proteins have minimum mobility. HDL shows the highest mobility, followed by VLDL, IDL, and LDL. (Option A ruled out) Lipoproteins with higher protein content move faster towards the anode. (Option B ruled out) Staining helps visualize lipoproteins , their electrophoretic mobility is crucial for identifying and classifying them. (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, enlarged tonsils, and orange-colored tonsils. His lipid profile shows very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Further investigation reveals that the patient has a rare genetic condition leading to severe HDL deficiency. Given these findings, which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 (ATP-binding cassette, sub-family A, member 1) gene . Pathophysiology: The ABCA1 protein is crucial for the efflux of cholesterol and phospholipids to apolipoprotein A-I (ApoA-I), forming HDL particles. Mutations in the ABCA1 gene impair this process, leading to a shortage of HDL and cholesterol accumulation in tissues such as the tonsils, liver, spleen, and peripheral nerves. Clinical Features: Greyish-Orange Tonsils: (Hallmark feature) Tonsils, become enlarged and acquire a greyish-orange hue due to the accumulation of cholesterol esters. Hepatosplenomegaly : Due to cholesterol and phospholipid accumulation. Peripheral Neuropathy: Multiple nerves can be individually affected due to cholesterol deposition in peripheral nerves, leading to peripheral neuropathy. LDLR gene mutations(Option B) are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, which primarily affects low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels, not HDL levels. APOE gene mutation (Option C) is associated with various lipid disorders and Alzheimer's disease. While APOE influences lipid metabolism, it does not specifically cause the severe HDL deficiency. PCSK9 gene mutations (Option D) are linked to familial hypercholesterolemia, affecting LDL cholesterol levels rather than HDL. These mutations result in increased LDL and cholesterol levels and are not associated with HDL deficiency.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of palmar xanthoma. She reports a family history of similar symptoms. Laboratory tests reveal elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, with a cloudy appearance of her plasma.What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: β -VLDL, Chylomicrons Cholesterol Level Increased Triglyceride Level Increased Appearance of Plasma Cloudy Metabolic Defect Abnormal Apo E Apo CII increased Features Palmar xanthomas Increased incidence of vascular disease Management Weight reduction Restrict intake of fat and cholesterol Administer polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) and drugs Type I (Familial chylomicronemia syndrome) (Option A): Characterized by lipoprotein lipase deficiency, causing severe hypertriglyceridemia, eruptive xanthomas, and a creamy layer over clear plasma. Type IIa (Familial hypercholesterolemia) (Option B): Results from an LDL receptor defect , leading to high LDL levels, atherosclerosis, and tuberous xanthomas. Type IV (Familial hypertriglyceridemia) (Option D) : Associated with elevated VLDL levels, glucose intolerance, and a cloudy or milky appearance of plasma, but not typically with palmar xanthomas.

questions.question: Match the apolipoproteins with their respective functions in lipid metabolism: Apolipoprotein Function 1) Apolipoprotein A-I a. Enhances lipoprotein lipase activity, facilitating triglyceride hydrolysis. 2) Apolipoprotein B-100 b. Involved in the transport of dietary lipids from the intestine to other tissues. 3) Apolipoprotein C-II c. Helps in reverse cholesterol transport, removing excess cholesterol from tissue back to liver. 4) Apolipoprotein E d. Essential for binding to LDL receptors on various tissues.
questions.explanation: Lipoprotein) Major protein component of HDL facilitates reverse cholesterol transport, removing excess cholesterol from tissues and transporting it back to the liver. Apolipoprotein B-100 LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) Main apolipoprotein of LDL; essential for binding to LDL receptors on various tissues , facilitating cholesterol uptake. Apolipoprotein B-48 Chylomicrons Main apolipoprotein of chylomicrons; involved in the transport of dietary lipids from the intestine to other tissues. Apolipoprotein C-II Chylomicrons, VLDL (Very-Low-Density Lipoprotein) Acts as a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase, enhancing triglyceride hydrolysis and aiding in lipoprotein metabolism. Apolipoprotein C-III VLDL, HDL Inhibits lipoprotein lipase activity, affecting triglyceride metabolism and lipoprotein clearance. Apolipoprotein E Chylomicrons, VLDL, HDL Facilitates the uptake of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins by cells through interactions with specific receptors; involved in lipid transport and metabolism. Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 23rd Edition, Page 249-251. Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Page 174, 175.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of progressive kidney dysfunction and recurrent episodes of hemolytic anemia. On examination, the patient is found to have corneal opacification on slit-lamp examination. His lipid profile shows high levels of cholesterol and lipoprotein X. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Acyltransferase deficiency). LCAT deficiency exists in two primary forms: Partial LCAT Deficiency (Fish eye disease) Complete LCAT Deficiency (Norum’s disease) LCAT Enzyme Activity Partial loss, mainly affecting corneal lipid metabolism Severe impairment or absence, leading to systemic issues Corneal Appearance Fish-eye appearance due to cholesterol ester accumulation Fisheye disease: similar corneal opacification Systemic Involvement Less severe, primarily ocular Severe: hemolytic anemia, CKD, early myocardial infarction, progressive End-stage renal disease Tangier disease(Option A) is associated with very low HDL levels and characteristic features such as orange tonsils and peripheral neuropathy. Familial hypercholesterolemia (Option B) typically presents with high LDL levels, xanthomas, and early cardiovascular disease, but not hemolytic anemia or corneal opacification. Niemann-Pick disease (Option D) is a lysosomal storage disorder involving neurological symptoms and organomegaly.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the primary function of Very Low-Density Lipoprotein (VLDL) in the body?

options.A: Transport of dietary cholesterol to the liver
options.B: Transport of triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues
options.C: Removal of cholesterol from peripheral tissues to the liver
options.D: Storage of excess cholesterol in adipose tissue

questions.explanation: such as muscle and adipose tissue, where they can be used for energy or stored. VLDL is rich in triglycerides and also contains cholesterol and apolipoproteins. As VLDL releases triglycerides to cells, it becomes intermediate density lipoprotein(IDL) and eventually low density lipoprotein(LDL). This conversion of VLDL to IDL and then to LDL is referred to as lipoprotein cascade pathway Transport of dietary cholesterol to the liver (Option A) - This function is primarily carried out by chylomicrons, not VLDL. Chylomicrons are responsible for transporting dietary lipids, including cholesterol, from the intestines to the liver. Removal of cholesterol from peripheral tissues to the liver (Option C) - This function is primarily carried out by high-density lipoprotein (HDL), not VLDL. HDL is involved in reverse cholesterol transport, carrying cholesterol away from the tissues and back to the liver for excretion. Storage of excess cholesterol in adipose tissue (Option D) - This is not a function of VLDL. Excess cholesterol can be stored in various tissues, but VLDL primarily transports triglycerides, while LDL and other mechanisms are involved in cholesterol storage and transport. Reference: Harper Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 250 & 251

questions.question: The lipid profile of 55 Y/O female is given below: Triglycerides 150 mg/dL Total cholesterol 350 mg/dL HDL 90 mg/dL Calculate LDL level of this patient.
questions.explanation: HDL+LDL+TG/5 mg/dL Substituting the values, 350 = 90+LDL+150/5 LDL = 350-90-30 = 230 mg/dL Friedwald’s equation is accurate when triglycerides levels are below 400 mg/dL. Options A, C and D are incorrect. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6960042/

questions.question: Which enzyme facilitates the conversion of discoidal HDL into spheroidal HDL in HDL metabolism?
questions.explanation: (aka Nascent HDL- amphipathic) into spheroidal HDL (aka Mature HDL- hydrophobic). It catalyzes the transfer of an acyl group from lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) to cholesterol, forming cholesteryl esters. HDL Metabolism HDL Formation: Formed in the liver and intestines as nascent, discoidal particles rich in apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I). Cholesterol Efflux: ABCA1 Transporter , transfers free cholesterol and phospholipids to nascent HDL. ABCG1 and SR-BI Transporters facilitate cholesterol efflux to HDL. Maturation of HDL: Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) converts discoidal HDL into spherical HDL by forming cholesterol esters that move to the core of HDL particles. HDL Remodeling: Phospholipid transfer protein (PLTP) and cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) modify HDL size and composition by transferring lipids between lipoproteins. Selective Uptake and HDL Recycling: Scavenger Receptor Class B Type I (SR-BI) facilitates selective uptake of cholesterol esters from HDL into hepatocytes. CETP transfers cholesteryl esters from HDL to VLDL and LDL for liver uptake. Excretion: The liver converts cholesterol into bile acids or secretes it into bile for excretion via intestines. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) (Option A) is an enzyme that hydrolyzes triglycerides in lipoproteins into free fatty acids and glycerol. Hepatic lipase (Option C) primarily hydrolyzes triglycerides and phospholipids in intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and low-density lipoproteins (LDL). Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (Option D) (CETP), facilitates the transfer of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides between lipoproteins. Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 23rd Edition, Page 253 Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Page 179, 180.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding bile acid synthesis regulation? 7 α -hydroxylation is the step which is suppressed Cholic acid suppresses the synthesis Farnesoid X receptor is activated Transcription of the CYP7A1 gene is suppressed

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fate of cholesterol? Chenodeoxycholic acid and cholic acid are the primary bile acids Glycine-taurine conjugation happens in liver peroxisomes Intestinal bacteria produce secondary bile acids
questions.explanation: acid are secondary bile acids. Primary bile acids are conjugated in liver peroxisomes. They are converted into glycine or taurine conjugates. Intestinal bacteria deconjugate and de-hydroxylase the glycine-taurine conjugates to form secondary bile acids. Fate of cholesterol: Note: The anions of bile acids and their glycine or taurine conjugates are referred to as bile salts. In the alkaline environment of bile, they are expected to exist in this form.

questions.question: Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the principal regulatory step of cholesterol synthesis?
questions.explanation: mevalonate, catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase Site- cytoplasm and smooth endoplasmic reticulum Regulation of HMG-CoA reductase: Category Regulation Method Mechanism Allosteric Modification Statins (e.g., Lovastatin) Competitive inhibition of HMG CoA reductase Covalent Modification AMP-activated Kinase Phosphorylates HMG CoA reductase, inactivating it Protein Phosphatase 1 Dephosphorylates HMG CoA reductase, activating it Induction or Repression Sufficient Cholesterol Suppresses transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene Low Dietary Cholesterol Increases transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene Insulin and Thyroxine Increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase (induction) Cortisol and Glucagon Decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase (repression) HMG CoA synthase (Option A) catalyzes the formation of HMG-CoA from acetyl-CoA and acetoacetyl-CoA, which is an upstream step in the cholesterol synthesis pathway but not the rate-limiting step. - HMG CoA Synthase is also a part of ketone body synthesis pathway (mitochondrial) - Cholesterol pathway enzyme is cytoplasmic Cytosolic thiolase (Option C) is involved in an upstream step of cholesterol synthesis by converting two molecules of acetyl-CoA into acetoacetyl-CoA, not directly involved in the regulatory step. Squalene epoxidase (Option D) catalyzes the conversion of squalene to squalene-2,3-epoxide, a downstream step in the cholesterol synthesis pathway, but it is not a regulatory step. Reference: Harper Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 260 Vasudevan Biochemistry, 7th edition, Page 171, 173
